qas.question: The policy of containment in Asia was aimed at what ideology?
What was the psychological turning point of the war?
When did this offensive take place?
When were US forces withdrawn from Vietnam?
The policy of supplying arms and war materiel for the Vietnamese to fight their own war was called what?
The policy of containment in Korea was aimed at what ideology?
What was the sociological turning point of the war?
When did this defense take place?
When were US forces withdrawn from China?
The policy of supplying arms and war materiel for the Chinese to fight their own war was called what?

context: The U.S. framed the war as part of its policy of containment of <a0_0><b5_0>Communism<b5_0/><a0_0/> in south Asia, but American forces were frustrated by an inability to engage the enemy in decisive battles, corruption and incompetence in the Army of the Republic of Vietnam, and ever increasing protests at home. <a1_0>The <b6_0>Tet Offensive<b6_0/><a1_0/> in <a2_0><b7_0>1968<b7_0/><a2_0/>, although a major military defeat for the NLF with half their forces eliminated, marked the psychological turning point in the war. With President Richard M. Nixon opposed to containment and more interested in achieving détente with both the Soviet Union and China, American policy shifted to <a4_0>"<b9_0>Vietnamization<b9_0/>,"<a4_0/> – providing very large supplies of arms and letting the Vietnamese fight it out themselves. After more than 57,000 dead and many more wounded, American forces withdrew in <a3_0><b8_0>1973<b8_0/><a3_0/> with no clear victory, and in 1975 South Vietnam was finally conquered by communist North Vietnam and unified.
